bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, February 1, 1929

div1.p: Laura Carter informs Russell of her progress on her father's book and reports that she has heard from Ramsey and Hayne regarding the International Health Board work.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, February 1, 1929

February 1, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
In reply to the inquiry contained in your much appreciated letter
of January 29th, just received, I would state that I personally do not consider it
necessary to order photostats from the official copy of the “Third Inves-
tigators' Report on the Non-Malarial Fevers in West Africa, ” nor even to
search for it through second-hand dealers. This, because I made out,
last summer, alternative bibliographic cards, covering all of Father's
references to Bacot's work in the above-mentioned report, from the “Sum-
mary of Conclusions” (arrived at by the Investigators in their Third Re-
port) as given in the “Fourth and Final Report” of the British West Af-
rican Yellow Fever Commission. Of course, one always prefers going back
to original sources, but I feel that, in the present instance, the time,
trouble and expense involved would not be justifiable, as we have been
able to give specific references and pagination in the Fourth and Final
Report. I am very grateful to you and to Mr. Van Wesep for the inter-
est you have taken in the matter.

I have been making good progress on the recopying and clarifying
of such bibliographic cards as need this treatment--many can stand as
they are. In doing this I am only doing what I had originally planned
as part of each day's work during the verification of bibliographic ref-
erences last spring and summer. However, after working from seven to ten
hours per diem on the actual “trail” of the references, I was thankful
enough simply to write down the exact source and put an “O. K.” at the
top of my bibliographic cards no matter how they looked! The only alter-
native would have been to cut down on the time expended in the actual search
search
-2-
for the references, which I was afraid to do as had anything happened to me no one else available
would have been familiar with both the MS and the languages involved, al
thoughin the other hand I felt sure that Miss Brown could interpret our verified cards,
even when they seemed involved to one not familiar with them. It was
then a case of “safety first”--keeping what time we had for essentials,;
just as after Father developed angina I even made narrow margins in my
typing in order to save even the small time involved in changing to fresh sheets of
paper, as much as possible.

Miss Brown has spent one evening here this week and we expect to
work together over this week-end.

Once more with sincere appreciation of your and Mr. Van Wesep's
kindness, I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director
International Health Division,
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
P. S. It has been very pleasant to hear of things West African from Dr.
Ramsey and also to get a long letter from Theodore Hayne, who is most
enthusiastic over his work.
P. P. S. Glad you sent a copy of your letter of Jan. 29th. to Dr. Frost
as, should he disagree with me in thinking my present bibliographic cards,
re Bacot's work, (as taken from the "Fourth and Final Report) sufficient
I shall know that I am wrong! LAC.
